div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, July 30, 1918
div1.opener:
I rec'd both the “Potter” -. & “Quantin”. The falter should
surely be published- whether it will be
who can guess
& why? H.R.C.
Love to your Mother
& to Mary & to Jennie
& Sally who is with you.
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Baltimore, MD
July 30, 1918
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
I got in Monday 6.30 A.M & was out
at Camp Humphreys' today & yester-
day- Things are fairly satisfactory there-, sui-
dow not too much satisfactory. I go to Quantico
tomorrow & it is probable that I will “breeze in”
Friday afternoon or evening. If I didn't rather
need to orient myself & regain my mental
equipoise. I would keep on to Petersburg &
thence, after say 2 or 3 days, to Newport News.
& Camp Eustis. All this is Griffitts Dis-
trict. which is not in a satisfactory condi-
tion- It is too big & too scattered to manage
without subdivisions - & he has not been suc-
cessful
successful in subdividing it. It will be a
hard struggle for the next 6 or 7 weeks & the
result, will partly depend on the weather
i.e. or the rainfall which for this months
has not been favorable. Have asked for a-
nother Asst. Engineer for him to take
the eastern part of his district- Langley
Field. Buckroe Beach & Hampton- leaving
the great section in the centre- from Mor-
rison to Hampton Roads & from James River
to Kecoughton. to Griffitts & Clark- with
3 gangs of men. Clark is a good drain-
age Engineer- but a poor handler of la-
bor. However after N. News I will have
need of a man of his Caliber at Peters-
burg. As the army has enlarged their hol-
dings. Hoping to see you within 72 hours
